The first numeration system

On the first page (History Tracers, 2024), we delved into the origins of the first numerical system, which found its inspiration in our very own fingers. However, this method posed a limitation; despite having assistance from others, there was a finite number of objects we could enumerate using this approach. To address this challenge, an ingenious solution emerged: the representation of fingers as symbolic units, akin to pipes (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., 2010, pp. 174 - 177, 180 - 182):

Figure 1: Representation of baboon bone adorned with markings. This image, credited to Enrique Silván Pobes, is featured in the scholarly work of Francisco A. Gonzáles Redondo et al.
The original is available in ResearchNet (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., 2010), and its inclusion here is made possible by the authorization of Doctor Francisco A. Gonzales Redondo.

Over the centuries, various numeration systems have been utilized, some of which endure to this day. In the following sections, we present an overview of contemporary systems alongside those that have recently fallen out of use.

Understanding the limits

Understanding the concept of limit is essential across various scientific disciplines, which is why we introduce it prior to delving into numerical systems.

When we enumerate using our hands, our limit is determined by the number of fingers we possess, making it a representation of the maximum value attainable.

Practice 1: Reaching the maximum
Begin by placing a set of objects within reach for enumeration, such as balls or grains of rice.
Close all fingers of one hand. Using the other hand, transfer the objects one by one from one side to the other. Each time an object is transferred, raise a finger. Repeat this process until all fingers are raised, signifying that you have reached the maximum limit of your hands.
 

The concept of limits also applies to descending enumeration.

Practice 2: Reaching the minimum
Continuing from the previous exercise, raise all fingers of one hand. Now, proceed to move the objects back one at a time. With each object returned, lower one finger. Repeat this process until all fingers are lowered, indicating that you have reached the minimum limit of your hands.
 

The notion of limits pervades various scenarios, serving as a threshold that is reached within a given context of study.

Some decimal numerical systems

While the earliest known numerical representations date back approximately 30,000 years (González Redondo, Francisco A., et al., 2010, pp. 174 - 177, 180 - 182), the decimal numerical systems commonly used in the Western world today emerged millennia later (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 48 - 53) However, these are not the only numerical systems devised throughout history. In the Andes region, the development of quipus by the Inca civilization stands as a remarkable example. Quipus served as a means to represent both numerical and non-numerical data (Zavala, José Manuel, et al., 2021 ; Rojas Leiva, Alejo, 2016, pp. 2).

Figure 2: Quipu representation. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers, 2024).

The Wari empire also utilized quipus (Rojas Leiva, Alejo, 2016, pp. 2 ; Conklin, William J., 1987, pp. 154 - 158), and there is speculation that the Caral civilization may have employed them (Ruta Caral, 2024 ; Youtube - Caral Perú Oficial, 2024) as far back as 5,000 years ago (Bobbio Rosas, Emilio Gustavo, 2016, pp. 82). However, consensus on this matter remains elusive (Mann, Charles C., 2005, pp. 1008 - 1009).

The Mesoamerican numerical system

In the Mesoamerican region, stretching from northern Mexico to northern Costa Rica (Kilroy-Ewbank, Lauren Dr.), it's evident that the use of fingers played a crucial role in their numerical system. However, unlike other cultures that solely relied on fingers, Mesoamericans extended their counting system to include toes, resulting in a vigesimal system (Marcus, Joyce, 2000).

The zero

Although the concept of zero holds immense importance in modern mathematics, its discovery is a relatively recent (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 44, 46 - 48). While the notion of zero emerged independently in various parts of the world, Auwalu Musa and Anna Blume suggest that there is uncertainty regarding whether the Maya civilization possessed a similar concept, particularly in light of the absence of new ancient texts to substantiate this claim (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 44 ; Blume, Anna, 2011).

Symbol selection

When employing a single symbol to represent numbers, such as the pipe ( | ), clarity can be compromised, leading to confusion for readers. Ambiguity arises when the separation between numbers is not distinct. To address this challenge, modern numerical systems adhere to the following principles:
  1. Each finger of the hand corresponds to a unique symbol.
  2. The initial symbol signifies the concept of emptiness (Musa, Auwalu, 2014, pp. 46)
  3. If a single symbol is insufficient for enumeration, an additional symbol is appended to its side.
In this text, we are going to study the first two characteristics using our fingers:

Figure 3: Fingers of a left hand: A - Thumb, B - Index, C - Middle, D - Ring, E - Little. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers, 2024).

This is not the unique format of expressing the Mesoamerican numbers. There is also a personified version, as outlined by Orlando Josué Casares Contreras, José M. Gamboa Cetina, and Venus Sarahí Estrella Cabrera (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, 2022, pp. 31 (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, 2022, pp. 31 (Magazine)).

Conclusion

On this page, we've delved into the association of fingers and toes with decimal numerical systems, tracing their usage over recent millennia. Additionally, we've examined two fundamental characteristics of these numerical systems.

Moving forward, our exploration will shift to delve deeper into the numerical sequence and further investigate the concept of limits.
